block.p: Heads of State Discuss War Trends at U.N. Summit President Clinton and other leaders took part in a Security Council meeting intended to concentrate on peacekeeping problems, but it quickly turned to a discussion about the causes of war in an age when ethnic cleansing and rape have become the tactical hallmarks of pickup armies that terrorize populations weakened by poverty or disease.

Yasir Arafat gave insufficient assurances that he would agree to a solution on Jerusalem, administration officials said after the Palestinian leader met with President Clinton, and the White House has begun to sense no breakthrough is coming.
After changing its story several times, the White House said Mr. Clinton and Fidel Castro did shake hands at a luncheon on Wednesday.

President Mohammad Khatami of Iran criticized democratic reformers in his country for holding unrealistic expectations, and he urged his people to avoid extremes in the name of security or freedom. He also criticized the international outrage over the prosecution and conviction of a group of Jews as spies.
A succession of leaders speaking on the second day of the Millennium Summit demanded that the industrialized world show more tangible charity toward the world's poor.

Russian Mogul Defies Kremlin Boris Berezovsky aggravated a dispute with President Vladimir V. Putin by announcing that he would put in trust his dominant stake in Russia's largest television network rather than surrender it to Kremlin control.

Labor Unrest in France A strike begun by truckers to protest spiraling fuel costs spread as workers from other sectors of the economy joined in the demonstrations, disrupting transportation systems throughout the country.

Vote on China Trade Bill The Senate voted, 92 to 5, to end preliminary debate and proceed to final consideration of a measure that would establish permanent trade relations with China and end Congress's annual review of Beijing's trade status.

Bush Scoffs at Grumbling, But Moves to Recast Image Gov. George W. Bush dismissed criticism from some Republicans over the direction of his campaign, but he also called himself ''the underdog'' and said he would restyle his campaign to put him in more intimate settings with voters. A poll by ABC News and The Washington Post had the race tied, with Mr. Bush and Mr. Gore each attracting 47 percent, while a Gallup poll for CNN and USA Today put Mr. Gore in the lead, 47 percent to 44 percent.
A rift has developed between the Bush organization and the Republican National Committee.
Mr. Bush and some advisers signaled new flexibility on debates.
Dark View of Bush's Plans Senator Joseph I. Lieberman said Gov. George W. Bush's economic plans would ''send us back down the drain of deficits, rising interest rates and rising unemployment.''
House Can't Override Tax Veto The House sustained President Clinton's veto of a Republican-sponsored repeal of the federal estate tax.
G.O.P. Alters Course on Drugs Leading Senate Republicans said they would try to pass legislation soon to help low-income elderly people buy prescription drugs.

A Lawyer's Lesser Cases Edward D. Fagan, who stands to earn millions in legal fees from multibillion-dollar Holocaust settlements with Swiss banks and German industry, left neglected personal-injury clients in his wake, according to court papers and interviews.
White Supremacists Lose Case An Idaho jury ordered leaders of the Aryan Nations to pay more than $6 million to victims of an attack by guards at the group's compound.
Overhaul of Juvenile Jails Louisiana agreed in federal court to change the way it runs juvenile prisons, pledging, for example, to protect inmates from abusive guards.

Modifying View of Christianity A large group of influential Jewish scholars and rabbis have signed a theological statement calling on Jews to relinquish their fear and mistrust of Christianity and to acknowledge recent efforts to amend Christian teaching on Judaism.

A Witness Against the Mob Explains Why He Turned Sean J. Richard, 35, the son-in-law of a reputed New Jersey mob boss, said in an interview that he decided to tell the authorities about corruption in the construction industry because he feared either a lengthy prison sentence from the government or a death sentence from the mob. His information figured in the racketeering indictments against 38 people announced in Manhattan this week.

A House for Sale The Westchester district attorney, Jeanine F. Pirro, and her husband, Albert J. Pirro Jr., who is to be sentenced on Sept. 28 for conspiracy and tax evasion, put their 8,000-square-foot house in Harrison on the market, seeking more than $5 million.

New School Year Begins New York City's 1.1 million public school students returned to classes as the chancellor said the board had complied with a court order requiring it to hire certified teachers for the worst elementary schools.
Walkouts by Teachers Teachers went on strike in Buffalo and in Hamilton Township, N.J.
A 170-Room Ancient Palace Archaeologists digging in a Guatemalan jungle found a Mayan palace dating from the eighth century.

Anti-Cancer Drug Warning Dutch researchers, questioning the prescription of tamoxifen for some women to prevent breast cancer, said women who took the drug for two years or more raised their risk of dying from a uterine cancer.
No Conclusion on Gulf Ailments A scientific panel said it could not say what had caused the symptoms known as gulf war syndrome.

Missed Signals of Tire Flaws Statistics from a widely used federal database show that fatal accidents involving Ford Explorers were almost three times as likely to be tire-related than fatalities involving other sport utility vehicles. But Ford, Firestone and federal safety regulators never detected the pattern.
Bridgestone/Firestone documents showed concern as early as February about rising warranty costs for the tires that the company recalled last month.

Profit Warning From DuPont The biggest chemical company in the nation warned that soaring costs for fuel and raw materials, the slide of the euro and possibly lower sales would push earnings for the rest of the year below expectations.
On Drugs and the Olympics A report financed by the White House drug policy office rebukes the International Olympic Committee as ineffective in fighting the use of performance-enhancing drugs.
Martin and Safin Advance Todd Martin beat Thomas Johansson, 6-4, 6-4, 3-6, 7-5, and Marat Safin beat Nicolas Kiefer, 7-5, 4-6, 7-6 (5),6-3, to make the Open semifinals.
Editorials: The economic scoreboard; Mr. Kerik sends a message; Howell Raines on summer reading and Elvis Presley. Columns: Thomas L. Friedman.
